hotspots.hotspot: Because the printer is using an older spelling style (the long 's' symbol=ƒ), Invisible looks like it is spelled with an f instead of an s.
Tryals is spelled with a y instead of an i. In some sources, (sic) appears to show that a mistake was part of the original document and not made in the translation.
Why was this source written? Part of the purpose is to inform about the witch trials.
If difficult to understand, break the sentence into parts. For example: Together with / Observations / upon the Nature / the Number / and the Operations / of the Devils.
What is the author's point of view? The author's language shows that he believed witches were real and those tried were guilty.
What information is missing or mistaken, and why? The author does not suggest that the defense of those tried will be examined.
This text tells you that the governor of the colony ordered the publication of this book.
The intended and most probable impact of the document was to persuade other people of the guilt of those tried and of the need for the witch trials.
Who is the audience for this source? The audience was likely learned people and people of power in New England and London.
This text tells you that this book is a second edition, printed in London, England. The first edition was printed in New England.

Gender

Mather was a man. The Puritans were a patriarchic society, in which men held supreme authority over women and children. It is also significant to note that most of those accused of and executed for witchcraft were women.

Ethnicity or nationality

A white American colonist who lived his life in Boston

Knowledge

First-hand knowledge as an observer of the witch trials and as a friend of several of the judges

Background

Well educated with two degrees from Harvard College and an interest in philosophy, religion, and medicine

Age

29 years old when he wrote this book

Occupation

A Congregational minister who enjoyed great influence in society

Beliefs

A Puritan who belonged to the Congregationalist Church and believed in the existence of the Devil and witchcraft
